item.title: Chart: For most offences, prison is the exception, not the rule
item.description:
Of the 720,000 non-motoring offences for which people were sentenced in 2017, only about 10% resulted in a prison sentence. Some convictions, like rape and robbery, almost always result in a prison sentence (at least for adult offenders), while other offences very rarely result in imprisonment.

item.title: Chart: Most people think the justice system is fair
item.description:
Across age, education, ethnic and employment groups, most people believe the criminal justice system as a whole is fair, but there are exceptions – for example, only 46% of people who identify as black agree.

larger image | annotated R code to produce this chart

Data source: Crime Survey for England and Wales, 2018

item.title: Police cuts haven't hit everywhere equally
item.description:
There are almost 22,000 fewer police officers in England and Wales than in 2010, but numbers haven’t dropped equally across police forces. One force (Surrey) has more officers now than 10 years ago, while officer numbers in forces like Humberside are increasing after steep cuts. But in almost half of forces, numbers are still falling despite a decade of often above-average cuts already.
